(disproves a conjecture of Schaefer andŠtefankovič, 2013 )
• The strong Hanani-Tutte theorem does not generalize to the orientable surface of genus 4:
Theorem 1: There is a graph of genus 5 that has an independently even drawing on the orientable surface of genus 4.
(disproves a conjecture of Schaefer andŠtefankovič, 2013 )

• Unified Hanani-Tutte theorem does not generalize to the torus:
Theorem 2: There is a graph G with the following two properties.

1) The graph G has an independently even drawing D on the torus, with a set W of four vertices such that every pair of edges with a common endpoint in W crosses an even number of times. 2) There is no embedding of G on the torus with the same rotations of the vertices of W as in D.

Let D be an independently even drawing of G in the plane where, in addition, every pair of edges with a common endpoint in W crosses an even number of times. Then G has a plane drawing where the rotations of vertices from W are the same as in D. Unified Hanani-Tutte theorem: (Pelsmajer-Schaefer-Štefankovič, 2006; Fulek-K.-Pálvölgyi, 2016) Let G be a graph and let W be a subset of vertices of G. Let D be an independently even drawing of G in the plane where, in addition, every pair of edges with a common endpoint in W crosses an even number of times. Then G has a plane drawing where the rotations of vertices from W are the same as in D. • W = ∅: strong • W = V (G): weak • The strong Hanani-Tutte theorem does not generalize to the orientable surface of genus 4:
